t: For the director of music. A psalm of David.
The*pn heavens declare the glory of God; the*ld skies proclaim the work of his hands.
Day*ln after day they pour forth speech; night*ld after night they reveal knowledge.
They*ln have no speech, they use no words; no*ld sound is heard from them.
Yet*ln their voice goes out into all the earth, their*ld words to the ends of the world. In*ln the heavens God has pitched a tent for the sun.
It*ld is like a bridegroom coming out of his chamber, like*ld a champion rejoicing to run his course.
It*ln rises at one end of the heavens and*ld makes its circuit to the other; nothing*ld is deprived of its warmth.
The*pn law of the Lord*s is perfect, refreshing*ld the soul. The*ln statutes of the Lord*s are trustworthy, making*ld wise the simple.
The*ln precepts of the Lord*s are right, giving*ld joy to the heart. The*ln commands of the Lord*s are radiant, giving*ld light to the eyes.
The*ln fear of the Lord*s is pure, enduring*ld forever. The*ln decrees of the Lord*s are firm, and*ld all of them are righteous.
They*pn are more precious than gold, than*ld much pure gold; they*ln are sweeter than honey, than*ld honey from the honeycomb.
By*ln them your servant is warned; in*ld keeping them there is great reward.
But*ln who can discern their own errors? Forgive*ld my hidden faults.
Keep*ln your servant also from willful sins; may*ld they not rule over me. Then*ln I will be blameless, innocent*ld of great transgression.
May*pn these words of my mouth and this meditation of my heart be*ld pleasing in your sight, Lord,*sld my Rock and my Redeemer.
